Titulo: Pleasent beach with easy access to the Romantic zone.
Review: Playa de Los Muertos ... "Deadman‚Äôs Beach," named for the bones of the local indigenous people found buried in the sand, or after the legendary pirate raids on the nearby village, it depends who you believe. Lots of beach sports are played here overlooked by an assortment of excellent restaurants and bars that are a party haven for PV's LGBTQ travelers. The pier lights up at night, and is also the starting point for day fishing trips, and boat rides to the more private and secluded beaches. The little seahorse statue is worth a photo as it has been replacing three times, due to serious storms removing it. TIP: The beach has a strong current, parents with children please take extra precautions when swimming.If you found this review informative, please check the box below. Thank you.

Review: Wow!  Crazy place!  We walked down Basilio Badillo, and ended up at Los Muertos.  We walked out onto the famous pier, and local kids were jumping off.  It was a summer weekend so packed with locals and visitors alike.  You can rent water sports like paddleboards.  We meant to come back because it was one large insane party place, and looked so fun, but didn't have time to return.  Lots of beachfront eateries, and shopping on the street side of the restaurants.  I wouldn't want to stay here unless I was a young party person (in which case, yes please!), but it is a great place to visit for the day.  I'd like to see it lit up at night, too.  It was very gay friendly, and good for families too.  We walked up the beach all the way to The Marina.

Review: Se cargan fotos de San Pancho, M√©xico tomadas 2022 - 2024 . ¬°Voy a menudo! San Pancho es un pintoresco pueblo surfero, en el Oc√©ano Pac√≠fico. La ciudad es plana y caminable, algunas colinas, calles empedradas, aceras. SP es el hogar de muchos restaurantes, cafeter√≠as, restaurantes, puestos de comida pop-up, tiendas lindas, farmacias, tiendas de comestibles, un peque√±o hospital (m√°s grandes no muy lejos). La playa es un tramo de una milla de playa transitable, ambos extremos est√°n marcados por acantilados rocosos y exuberante selva, arboledas de palmeras, etc. Grandes sesiones de fotos, tomar zapatos para caminar en √°reas rocosas, sentarse y disfrutar de la vista. San Pancho est√° en la 'Riviera Nayarit'; Nayarit es el nombre del estado. Nayarit es un exuberante paisaje selv√°tico con flores tropicales, arboledas de palmeras, aves tropicales, bosque denso. San Pancho y Nayarit difiere de Cabo San Lucas y Baja California, siendo Baja California / Cabo San Lucas un paisaje m√°s est√©ril y des√©rtico. La temporada alta es de noviembre a mayo, y es cuando los propietarios estadounidenses y canadienses regresan a su "hogar lejos de casa" y el turismo se activa. La temporada baja es junio - octubre, cuando el clima se calienta y se vuelve h√∫medo, puede llover fuerte por la noche, y puede haber tormentas el√©ctricas y rel√°mpagos sustanciales en septiembre / octubre. Siempre es divertido tener estas tormentas salvajes por la noche! Restaurantes, cafeter√≠as y servicios est√°n abiertos para negocios durante la temporada alta, sin embargo, algunos restaurantes cierran durante un mes durante julio agosto septiembre. No importa la temporada, siempre encontrar√° un mont√≥n de restaurantes disponibles, farmacias abiertas, la mayor√≠a de las tiendas abiertas y varias tiendas de comestibles siempre abiertas. No hay "mala" √©poca para visitar San Pancho, pero hay temporadas "altas" y "bajas", debido al clima. La mayor√≠a de los restaurantes toman tarjetas de cr√©dito (no Amex), sin embargo, a veces wifi est√° ca√≠do, por lo tanto, el deslizamiento de la tarjeta de cr√©dito no funciona. Siempre es una buena idea llevar algo de dinero en efectivo encima, y preguntar antes de ordenar! Hay un mont√≥n de cajeros autom√°ticos en San Pancho - preguntar a cualquier tienda para la ubicaci√≥n m√°s cercana. La mayor√≠a de los lugares aceptar√°n USD al tipo de cambio actual, sin embargo, es bueno tener siempre pesos en usted. Los camareros le traer√°n la m√°quina de transferencia de tarjetas de cr√©dito y la pasar√°n en su presencia. Nunca he tenido problemas con el fraude crediticio. San Pancho es caminable, no se necesita coche. Hay taxis locales de San Pancho que esperan en el centro de la ciudad, y est√°n disponibles para conducir a los pueblos cercanos como Sayulita, Lo De Marcos, etc., as√≠ como llevarlo al aeropuerto. No vale la pena alquilar un coche a menos que planee hacer mucho conducir a otras ciudades. Los alquileres de coches son caros en M√©xico, la conducci√≥n en Puerto Vallarta puede ser totalmente confusa, y la polic√≠a local tiende a meterse en los coches de alquiler (pueden verlos a trav√©s de la matr√≠cula). En San Pancho, a menos que tenga un lugar designado para estacionarse, tendr√° dificultades para encontrar un lugar para estacionarse. Las carreteras de San Pancho son predominantemente empedradas, y puede haber grietas en las aceras (solo para su informaci√≥n). Sin embargo, es muy factible caminar, disfrutar de esos gallos de madrugada corriendo por ah√≠, los due√±os de tiendas prepar√°ndose para el d√≠a, los vendedores de pi√±a reabasteciendo sus meticulosos carritos, etc. Caminar por la ma√±ana temprano es divertido! Los atardeceres son de color rosa, p√∫rpura y naranja. Muchos lugare√±os y visitantes esperan en la playa y aplauden mientras se pone el sol. Las puestas de sol de San Pancho son realmente algunas de las m√°s incre√≠bles del mundo, y SP se ha hecho conocido por sus puestas de sol sensacionales. La playa es oscura por la noche en los extremos norte y sur; la arena puede cambiar y volverse plana o monta√±osa dependiendo de la estaci√≥n y las tormentas. La playa es caminable, y est√° a 1 milla de extremo a extremo. Las casas a lo largo de la playa tienden a mantener las luces exteriores apagadas, ya que las luces brillantes perturban a las tortugas que anidan, de las cuales San Pancho es el hogar de muchas 'tortugas. ' Para obtener informaci√≥n sobre el programa de tortugas y para presenciar c√≥mo se liberan tortugas (muy divertido para la familia, y es gratis), por favor busque en Google San Pancho Turtle Program; la informaci√≥n se puede encontrar en su sitio web, y su Instagram siempre se actualiza con la fecha y hora de las liberaciones de tortugas en la playa. ¬°Ver cientos de tortugas beb√© del tama√±o de una mano meneando su camino hacia el mar es realmente incre√≠ble de presenciar! No se permite tocar o manipular las tortugas, simplemente retrocede y presencia este peque√±o milagro! ¬°Divi√©rtete! Noviembre 2024

Los alquileres de coches son caros en M√©xico, la conducci√≥n en Puerto Vallarta puede ser totalmente confusa, y la polic√≠a local tiende a meterse en los coches de alquiler (pueden verlos a trav√©s de la matr√≠cula). En San Pancho, a menos que tenga un lugar designado para estacionarse, tendr√° dificultades para encontrar un lugar para estacionarse. Las carreteras de San Pancho son predominantemente empedradas, y puede haber grietas en las aceras (solo para su informaci√≥n). Sin embargo, es muy factible caminar, disfrutar de esos gallos de madrugada corriendo por ah√≠, los due√±os de tiendas prepar√°ndose para el d√≠a, los vendedores de pi√±a reabasteciendo sus meticulosos carritos, etc. Caminar por la ma√±ana temprano es divertido! Los atardeceres son de color rosa, p√∫rpura y naranja. Muchos lugare√±os y visitantes esperan en la playa y aplauden mientras se pone el sol. Las puestas de sol de San Pancho son realmente algunas de las m√°s incre√≠bles del mundo, y SP se ha hecho conocido por sus puestas de sol sensacionales. La playa es oscura por la noche en los extremos norte y sur; la arena puede cambiar y volverse plana o monta√±osa dependiendo de la estaci√≥n y las tormentas. La playa es caminable, y est√° a 1 milla de extremo a extremo. Las casas a lo largo de la playa tienden a mantener las luces exteriores apagadas, ya que las luces brillantes perturban a las tortugas que anidan, de las cuales San Pancho es el hogar de muchas 'tortugas. ' Para obtener informaci√≥n sobre el programa de tortugas y para presenciar c√≥mo se liberan tortugas (muy divertido para la familia, y es gratis), por favor busque en Google San Pancho Turtle Program; la informaci√≥n se puede encontrar en su sitio web, y su Instagram siempre se actualiza con la fecha y hora de las liberaciones de tortugas en la playa. ¬°Ver cientos de tortugas beb√© del tama√±o de una mano meneando su camino hacia el mar es realmente incre√≠ble de presenciar! No se permite tocar o manipular las tortugas, simplemente retrocede y presencia este peque√±o milagro! ¬°Divi√©rtete! Noviembre 2024.

Titulo: Great Vacation, Need to Know Mexico
Review: We‚Äôre a family of 5 with kids 10, 8 and 4. Haven‚Äôt been to Mexico in about 15 years. What a welcomed return!! We chose San Pancho as it seemed a little less busy than Sayulita and we were welcomed with a beach that boasted a great surf (bit sketchy for the kids so be wary) and so much beach space it was easy to forget there were others around us. The restaurant selection is great! We were here for 10 days and only ate at the same place once, and that was only because we loved it so much (La Ola Rica). We rented a home on Air BnB and got a car service to town from Puerto Vallarta. We will definitely be planning a trip back here and during that time will be able to give a 5 star rating. The only point right now is that San Pancho is a newer tourist place (again what we saw as a bonus) so it‚Äôs still a bit rough around the edges. So for those who are looking for a manicured holiday maybe just come here for a day trip. For those who are looking to speak Spanish (or in our case bumble through a few broken phrases), relax with barely anyone around, ‚Äúlive like a local‚Äù, have alone beach time, eat amazing food, hear great music, watch local shows, and sit in hot sun with no clouds allllll day long, then San Pancho is the place for you. A little research, some sense of adventure and flexible attitude and you‚Äôll pleased as punch. Thank you San Pancho for a great vacation!

Titulo: Just beautiful, amazing and every other superlative
Review: We spent two weeks at the Riu Palce Pacifico, from from 27th January to 10th February. It is situated along the horseshoe shaped coastline of the Bay of Banderas, which measures about forty miles long and about 20 miles wide. The bay and it's waters receive natural protection from the mighty Sierra Madre mountain range which frames the bay, which is at the foot of the mountain range. We were reliably informed that it is the largest natural bay in Mexico. Due to the deep waters in the Bay, fishing there is reportedly some of the best in the world. It also hosts the frequent visitors, Humpback Whales and dolphins, sea turtles and rays reside here. A fellow guest informed us that they saw an alligator in the sea Almost on a daily basis, from our sunbeds on Playa Riu Palace Pacifico, we were treated to a display of whales and dolphins surfacing in the Bay. It was an amazing sight to see a whale splash down on the sea and then about 10 seconds later hear the booming sound of the whale hitting the water, brilliant. Our beach, Playa Riu Palace Pacifico, is a turtle conservation and nesting area for turtles. One day we were privileged to see a batch of turtles hatch, totally at the wrong time, and scurry towards the sea. Fellow holidaymakers, on the beach, provided protection on their way from the eagerly awaiting hungry pelicans. It is possible to take a boat tour, from Puerto Vallarta Harbour, to see whales. We could see numerous boats out at sea on a daily basis. It appeared that the boats would wait till a pod of whales was spotted and then speed to the area. A variety of water sports and activities, including wind surfing and boarding are popular in the Bay. Another wonderful sight is to sit with a cold beer and watch the sun set across the bay. Our room was on the 7th floor of the Hotel, sea facing, we were treated to some wonderful views of the Bay. It is possible to enjoy the Bay and all it has to offer directly from your sunbed. We did see slightly different views as we walked the beach, six and a bit kilometres in one direction and nearly three kilometres in the other. The City of Puerto Vallarta is within the Bay, it is an enjoyable experience to walk along the Malecon, see all the unusual statues and sculptures with the backdrop of this beautiful Bay.
TituloReview: Just beautiful, amazing and every other superlative. We spent two weeks at the Riu Palce Pacifico, from from 27th January to 10th February. It is situated along the horseshoe shaped coastline of the Bay of Banderas, which measures about forty miles long and about 20 miles wide. The bay and it's waters receive natural protection from the mighty Sierra Madre mountain range which frames the bay, which is at the foot of the mountain range. We were reliably informed that it is the largest natural bay in Mexico. Due to the deep waters in the Bay, fishing there is reportedly some of the best in the world. It also hosts the frequent visitors, Humpback Whales and dolphins, sea turtles and rays reside here. A fellow guest informed us that they saw an alligator in the sea Almost on a daily basis, from our sunbeds on Playa Riu Palace Pacifico, we were treated to a display of whales and dolphins surfacing in the Bay. It was an amazing sight to see a whale splash down on the sea and then about 10 seconds later hear the booming sound of the whale hitting the water, brilliant. Our beach, Playa Riu Palace Pacifico, is a turtle conservation and nesting area for turtles. One day we were privileged to see a batch of turtles hatch, totally at the wrong time, and scurry towards the sea. Fellow holidaymakers, on the beach, provided protection on their way from the eagerly awaiting hungry pelicans. It is possible to take a boat tour, from Puerto Vallarta Harbour, to see whales. We could see numerous boats out at sea on a daily basis. It appeared that the boats would wait till a pod of whales was spotted and then speed to the area. A variety of water sports and activities, including wind surfing and boarding are popular in the Bay. Another wonderful sight is to sit with a cold beer and watch the sun set across the bay. Our room was on the 7th floor of the Hotel, sea facing, we were treated to some wonderful views of the Bay. It is possible to enjoy the Bay and all it has to offer directly from your sunbed. We did see slightly different views as we walked the beach, six and a bit kilometres in one direction and nearly three kilometres in the other. The City of Puerto Vallarta is within the Bay, it is an enjoyable experience to walk along the Malecon, see all the unusual statues and sculptures with the backdrop of this beautiful Bay.

Titulo: Fun and educational for the whole family
Review: We took the Bahia Allegre catamaran for a day in the Bay. The crew was the best!!! Safety first, and alot of fun. They offered breakfast, lunch and drinks. Alcohol was only available after we were done with all the activities. They included: snorkeling, Kayaking, paddle board, and swimming. All of that in the clean and beautiful water of the Bandera Bay.We saw dolphins and on the way back we saw a whale!!! Majestic, unforggetable time.There 12 in our group, ages 8 to 58, and we all had a wonderful time.Hats off to Luis and the lifeguard with 30 year experience on board. They were top notch, highly recommend this company.

Review: On Monday 16th April we took a speedboat ride across the Bay, from Nuevo Vallarta to Boca de Tomatlan and our return journey as part of our Vallarta Adventures outdoor activities tour. It was a wonderful travelling experience as our boat sped across the top of the water, we were able to appreciate the size of the Bay and the spectacular mountains and their domination of the skyline.This Bay is situated on the west-central coast of the Mexican Pacific coastline, and is about 65 miles long.We asked our Tour Guide if there were any whales or dolphins in the Bay, he advised us that there were none, they had moved on some weeks ago to different waters, so sadly we saw nothing.Puerto Vallarta, Bucerias and Punta Mita are the largest towns within the Bay, also home to Puerto Vallarta and Nuevo Vallarta marinas. It is a favourite tourist location and there are a large number of hotels, golf courses and condominiums along the Bay.We stayed in Nuevo Vallarta for 2 weeks and very much enjoyed the views of the Bay which is flanked on all land sides by imposing mountains, Sierras. They are Sierra Vallejo on the northern part, Sierra Cuale to the East and Sierra El Tuito to the south and southeast.These contribute to the stunning backdrop to the Bay.Local tour guides will have you believe it is the largest bay in the world, the reality is somewhere else is.

On Monday 16th April we took a speedboat ride across the Bay, from Nuevo Vallarta to Boca de Tomatlan and our return journey as part of our Vallarta Adventures outdoor activities tour. It was a wonderful travelling experience as our boat sped across the top of the water, we were able to appreciate the size of the Bay and the spectacular mountains and their domination of the skyline.This Bay is situated on the west-central coast of the Mexican Pacific coastline, and is about 65 miles long.We asked our Tour Guide if there were any whales or dolphins in the Bay, he advised us that there were none, they had moved on some weeks ago to different waters, so sadly we saw nothing.Puerto Vallarta, Bucerias and Punta Mita are the largest towns within the Bay, also home to Puerto Vallarta and Nuevo Vallarta marinas. It is a favourite tourist location and there are a large number of hotels, golf courses and condominiums along the Bay.We stayed in Nuevo Vallarta for 2 weeks and very much enjoyed the views of the Bay which is flanked on all land sides by imposing mountains, Sierras. They are Sierra Vallejo on the northern part, Sierra Cuale to the East and Sierra El Tuito to the south and southeast.These contribute to the stunning backdrop to the Bay.Local tour guides will have you believe it is the largest bay in the world, the reality is somewhere else is.

Review: We went on a snorkeling/whale-watching trip, and while the snorkeling wasn't great, the whale watching was amazing! It was mating season so we saw a lot of action. There was a group of about 10 of them in one spot! One whale came right up next to our little boat! We also went over to the Marieta Islands where we saw blue-footed boobies and other birds. It was great!

Titulo: one of the worlds most beautiful bays & city setting
Review: My friend & I took two day long trips out into Banderas Bay during our 10 day visit.   We took a Vallarta Adventures dive trip out to the Marrietas Islands and also a day luxury sailing day trip.  When returning from diving we were surrounded by the biggest school of dolphins I ever saw.  There were hundreds, and the captain stopped our boat so we could enjoy the amazing sight.  We also saw many frigate birds, both blue- footed and brown boobies, brown pelicans, and gulls.  A cruise on the bay is a must outing when visiting Puerto Vallarta.

We took a Vallarta Adventures dive trip out to the Marrietas Islands and also a day luxury sailing day trip.  When returning from diving we were surrounded by the biggest school of dolphins I ever saw.  There were hundreds, and the captain stopped our boat so we could enjoy the amazing sight.  We also saw many frigate birds, both blue- footed and brown boobies, brown pelicans, and gulls.  A cruise on the bay is a must outing when visiting Puerto Vallarta.

Titulo: Many small villages and large towns
Review: Banderas Bay is home to a large number of towns and cities.  Much of the coastline is building up, but there are still smaller villages scattered about and they are always good to visit. North of Puerto Vallarta, which is the biggest city and just about center of the bay, you can drive to the smaller villages and towns.  Punta Mita & Bucerias are a couple of the larger areas and have interesting town centers.  They are worth a drive. South of Puerto Vallarta lie Mismaloya and Boca de Tomelin.  Mismaloya is tied to the movie "Night of the Iguana", although it has changed extensively since Elizabeth Taylor's visits. Bica is a thriving small port town; many water taxi routes using the port today.  boca is the last coastal town on the bay, from here the road cuts inland.  Any village to the south are accessed mainly by water taxi although a few have roads through the mountain originating mainly in El Tuito. The main villages along this stretch include Animas, Yelapa, Quimixto, Pizota, Conchas and Chimo. Yelapa is the largest of these and has water taxi service from los Muertos Pier in Puerto Vallarta.  It has a nice waterfall that can be hiked to, worthwhile (Pizota has a waterfall as well).  It also has a nice pier/dock...a few of the villages have none, necessitating a jump onto the surf from the water taxi.  Chimo collects passengers in a small canoe and transports them from the taxi to the beach. Quimixto is a fair sized settlement, Pizota has about 80 residents, Conchas is just 24 palapa style homes and Chimo residents number about 100.The water taxi ride is beautiful, taking just over an hour from Boca to Chimo, so days have heavy seas, so sit to the back of the boat if you can for a smoother ride. The taxi runs twice a day from Boca to Chimo, roughly 150 pesos each way (new rates may be in effect). Yelapa, Quimixto and Chimo have restaurants so they are good choices for day trips.  Pizota has a family or two who will cook if you give them advance notice--you may be eating in their homes. Most all the villages have some sort of accommodations available, Yelapa having the widest selection. Many places are listed on Airbnb or VRBO websites. This southern section of Banderas Bay is well worth exploring.

Titulo: Bay Of Banderas: The Jewel In The Crown Of Puerto Vallarta
Review: My  husband & I spent over a month enjoying views of Banderas Bay, this winter. We rented a cliff top condo in Conchas Chinas for the first half of of stay..This area was about a five minute bus ride from downtown PV. It was the area where the Sierra Madre Mountains cascaded down to meet the waters of Banderas Bay. We watched whales in the bay from our balcony. We had happy hours at Lindo Mar Resort & watched the sunset over Banderas Bay. We ate many meals on our balcony while we enjoyed its beauty & serenity. Our second condo was in an area just north of downtown PV. We were high on a hill & had expansive territorial Bay & city views. We spent hours on our balcony enjoying the marine action on the bay. Cruise ships, yachts, sailboats, pirate ships, fishing boats, parasailing, fireworks, seabirds, & more captured our attention during the day. Sunsets were glorious multicolored events. Truly magical!We were not content just to look a the dark blue water of Banderas Bay. We walked its shores along the Malecon. We ate & drank at waterside restaurants. We walked the beaches of Los Muertos, el Camerones, & Mismaoya. We swam in it. This 62 mile bay was truly the jewel in the crown of Puerto Vallarta. I look forward to spending another winter's month gazing at its beauty.

Review: Review for the thursday night markets here. A lot of booths here, mostly selling little trinkets and souvenirs. Some of the booths have similar or even identical stuff. The price initially offered is not cheap. I think it's pretty much expected you'll have to haggle a bit. It should be pretty easy to haggle it down to at least 50% of the original price. If you are persistent enough and have enough time and energy to haggle more, you can probably cut the price down even further. Whether that's worth it is up to you to decide.I was hoping that there would be more food stalls but I couldn't find any except for a few down at the tail end of the marina towards the south. We were pretty hungry by then but most of the restaurants were already full or booked out so we ended up taking a uber somewhere else for food.

Review: We had a wonderful experience at Playa Las Gemelas today. We wanted to go to a beach outside of PV proper and Yelapa seemed too far for two women traveling here for our first time. It was a Tuesday in November so it was quiet, which was welcomed. It seemed more locals, either from nearby towns or the condos on the beach. But the water was clean and clear with mild waves, the shells were gorgeous and the water temperature couldn't be beat. We Uber'd there instead of the bus. You're dropped on the side of the highway to take very steep and unkempt stairs down to the water (not handicap friendly), which opens up onto the beach. There, vendors make food, rent tables and chairs and have other fun things to look at / buy. You won't be disappointed.

We didn‚Äôt bring anything other than towels so we paid for two chairs, a small table and umbrella for 350 MX pesos. They also sell fresh fruit and coconuts. We got there around 11am and it was still pretty empty/quiet but once 1pm hit it got very crowded with all locals.
